Specific Details: Business priorities for Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade and Defence.
DPOs Lobbied: Brendan Smith|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Business priorities for Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade and Defence.
Intended Results: Government must ensure the interests of Ireland and our business community are protected during Brexit negotiations.::Government should continue to collaborate with peers in international forums such as the World Economic Forum, EU, the OECD and the WTO as well as bilaterally with other states to ensure that international policies will enable the Irish economy to thrive.::Government should further develop trade and investment opportunities with African partners.::Government should remain engaged at EU level in the negotiation of free trade agreements (FTAs) between the EU and third countries.::Changes to the Fiscal Compact at a European level are needed in order to facilitate increased investment spending.

Intended Results: Ireland takes a stronger role in conflict resolution in relation to Syrian crisis
Lobbying Activities: Email requesting a PQ on Ireland's response to the Syrian crisis.|Email|1

Specific Details: Implications for the Irish Mushroom Sector as result of Brexit
DPOs Lobbied: Andrew Doyle|Minister of State|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine::Bill Callanan|Chief Inspector|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine::Michael Creed|Minister|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine::Heather Humphreys|Minister|Department of Arts, Heritage and the Gaeltacht::Brendan Smith|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Jackie Cahill|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Aidan O'Driscoll|Secretary General|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine
Subject Matter: Implications for the Irish Mushroom Sector as result of Brexit
Intended Results: That the EU Producer Organisation (PO) funding would be paid to producers for 2014, out as soon as possible::That the exceptional State Aid measure allowing for a provision of short term loans to cater for liquidity gaps in the Dairy, Pigmeat, Fruit & Vegetable Sectors is implemented::To temporarily reduce the lower rate of employer PRSI from 8.5% to 4.25%. This measure existed between 2001 and 2013 as part of the then Government's Jobs' initiative
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: IFA President Joe Healy and IFA Horticulture Chairman Gerry Reilly

Specific Details: Amnesty's support for Control of Economic Activity (Occupied Territories) Bill, and need for regulation of digital tourism in illegal Israeli settlements on occupied Palestinian land, including Airbnb Ireland

Lobbying Activities:

Specific Details: During the 2019 European Elections, Calor contacted a number of MEP's and MEP candidates on the importance of EU energy policy for Ireland in the period 2020 to 2050. Calor enclosed a copy of its submission to Ireland's Draft National Energy and Climate Plan (2021-2030) and requested an opportunity to discuss Calor’s business in Ireland and energy policy development for rural communities and businesses.
DPOs Lobbied: Seán Kelly|MEP|European Parliament::Mairead McGuinness|MEP|European Parliament::Deirdre Clune|MEP|European Parliament::Billy Kelleher|MEP|European Parliament::Ciarán Cuffe|MEP|European Parliament::Brendan Smith|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: During the 2019 European Elections, Calor contacted a number of MEP's and MEP candidates on the importance of EU energy policy for Ireland in the period 2020 to 2050. Calor enclosed a copy of its submission to Ireland's Draft National Energy and Climate Plan (2021-2030) and requested an opportunity to discuss Calor’s business in Ireland and energy policy development for rural communities and businesses.
Intended Results: Introduction to Calor Ireland and highlighting the importance of EU energy policy for the heat and transport sectors in Ireland, in particular off-grid rural homes and businesses.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Catherine Hannon, Public Affairs and Sustainability Manager

Specific Details: Misean Cara post-Budget 2021 note to Oireachtas Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.  Misean Cara is writing to bring to your attention the Joint Committee’s call in its Review of the Irish Aid Programme in February 2018 for Government to “examine opportunities to increase funding to missionary bodies.”
DPOs Lobbied: Charles Flanagan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Brendan Smith|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Misean Cara post-Budget 2021 note to Oireachtas Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.  Misean Cara is writing to bring to your attention the Joint Committee’s call in its Review of the Irish Aid Programme in February 2018 for Government to “examine opportunities to increase funding to missionary bodies.”
Intended Results: Scaled up missionary funding within the bilateral ODA envelope of Irish ODA to better match the scale of unmet demand among our members and their potential for transformational change on the ground in over 50 countries. The increased funding announced in Budget '21 affords an important opportunity to increase funding to CSOs in Ireland & the Global South, including missionary groups, for effective development work that is particularly focused on marginalised & excluded groups in line with RFBF.
Lobbying Activities:
From: Eamonn Casey <ecasey@miseancara.ie>
Sent: Thursday 29 October 2020 18:07
To: charles.flanagan@oireachtas.ie <charles.flanagan@oireachtas.ie>
Cc: jcfad@oireachtas.ie <jcfad@oireachtas.ie>
Subject: Misean Cara post-Budget 2021 note to Oireachtas Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence 

Extract:
I am writing to follow up with the Joint Committee about Ireland's development cooperation programme, and particularly the place of missionaries in development as represented by Misean Cara.

With the welcome Budget announcement of €867 million investment in ODA, and as Misean Cara members and overseas partners highlight the need for additional resources (ever before extra COVID19 demands) which it is unable to provide at current levels of funding, Misean Cara is writing to bring to your attention the Joint Committee’s call in its Review of the Irish Aid Programme in February 2018 for Government to “examine opportunities to increase funding to missionary bodies.”|Email|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Eamonn Casey, Project Officer, Misean Cara

Specific Details: Farm Assist Scheme
DPOs Lobbied: Brendan Smith|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Farm Assist Scheme
Intended Results: To acknowledge, Farm Assist recipients during the period of 1999-2007 recently discovered that they were not entitled to a full State Contributory pension.::The reason given was that temporary/permanent Farm Assist recipients during 1999-2007 did not make PRSI contributions nor were they granted credited contributions. The farmers in question were not aware nor advised to continue making voluntary contributions.::This break in their PRSI contributions is preventing the affected farmers from claiming a full State Contributory pension. To establish has progress been made on this anomaly highlighted with Minister Humphreys?
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Donal Sheehan IFA Farm Business Policy Executive.

Specific Details: European Parliament Motion to Limit the use of Animal Medicines.
DPOs Lobbied: Barry Andrews|MEP|European Parliament::Billy Kelleher|MEP|European Parliament::Chris MacManus|MEP|European Parliament::Ciarán Cuffe|MEP|European Parliament::Clare Daly|MEP|European Parliament::Colm Markey|MEP|European Parliament::Deirdre Clune|MEP|European Parliament::Frances Fitzgerald|MEP|European Parliament::Grace O'Sullivan|MEP|European Parliament::Luke 'Ming' Flanagan|MEP|European Parliament::Maria Walsh|MEP|European Parliament::Mick Wallace|MEP|European Parliament::Seán Kelly|MEP|European Parliament::Brendan Smith|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: European Parliament Motion to Limit the use of Animal Medicines.
Intended Results: That MEPs from Ireland reject the motion before the European Parliament that would limit the use of animal medicines.::To highlight that farmers are responsible users of medicines to treat animal bacterial diseases. Restricting them could jeopardise food safety and food security.  The motion objects to the Delegated Act on the use of Antimicrobial Resistance.::That strict controls around the use of animal medicines should be a sufficient safeguard, without imposing further unreasonable restrictions.::To highlight that antibiotics are only allowed with a prescription and only following physical examination, good husbandry and proper diagnosis.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Pat Farrell IFA Animal Health Chair, Liam MacHale IFA Director Brussels
